cases.stem: 56M presents with a 2 hour history of sudden onset chest pain radiating to his jaw.

investigations.name: ECG
investigations.result: ST elevation in leads II, III, and aVF

investigations.name: Coags
investigations.result:
PT: 13.5: (11–14 seconds)
INR: 1.1: (0.8–1.2)
aPTT: 32: (25–35 seconds)
D-dimer: 0.3: (<0.5 µg/mL FEU)
Fibrinogen: 2.8: (2.0–4.0 g/L)

investigations.name: EUC
investigations.result:
Sodium: 140: (135–145 mmol/L)
Potassium: 4.0: (3.5–5.0 mmol/L)
Chloride: 102: (95–105 mmol/L)
Bicarbonate: 24: (22–28 mmol/L)
Urea: 5.0: (2.5–7.5 mmol/L)
Creatinine: 80: (60–110 µmol/L)

investigations.name: LFT
investigations.result:
Bilirubin: 10: (0–20 µmol/L)
ALT: 25: (10–40 U/L)
AST: 20: (10–40 U/L)
ALP: 80: (30–120 U/L)
GGT: 25: (10–50 U/L)
Total Protein: 70: (60–80 g/L)
Albumin: 45: (35–50 g/L)

investigations.name: Echocardiogram
investigations.result: Hypokinesis of the inferior wall with an ejection fraction of 45%

investigations.name: CXR
investigations.result: Normal cardiac silhouette, no pulmonary oedema or consolidation.

investigations.name: Coronary Angiogram
investigations.result: 90% occlusion of the right coronary artery

investigations.name: CT Angiogram
investigations.result: 90% occlusion of the right coronary artery

investigations.name: Stress Test
investigations.result: Patient condition becomes a lot worse...

questions.prompt: What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Given ST elevation in 2 contiguous leads + chest pain, a provisional diagnosis of STEMI should be made until proven otherwise. The unremarkable chest x-ray can help rule out respiratory causes of chest pain (pneumothorax, pneumonia) and cardiac causes (aortic dissection, pericardial effusion). Troponins are likely to be normal within 2 hours of symptom onset. 
 
• ST elevation of II, III and aVF suggests inferior MI
• ST elevation of V5, V6, I and aVL suggests lateral MI
• ST elevation of V1-4 suggests anterior MI

sources.name: Pathway for Acute Coronary Syndrome Assessment (PACSA) Flow Chart

questions.prompt: What is your immediate supportive management?
questions.explanation: Regarding initial management, the NSW PACSA flowchart suggests 300mg aspirin (oral) unless contraindicated, as well as administration of glyceryl trinitrate (sublingual). Supplemental oxygen is not required in stable patients if their SPO2 is above 93%. Morphine (2.5-5 mg IV) can be given if pain persists, often with an antiemetic e.g. 10mg metoclopramide.

sources.name: Pathway for Acute Coronary Syndrome Assessment (PACSA) Flow Chart
Emergency Medicine: Diagnosis and Management 6th Edition (Brown & Cadogan, 2011)

questions.prompt: What is your definitive management?
options: PCI within 60 minutes / fibrinolysis within 12 hours
PCI within 6 hours / fibrinolysis within 24 hours
questions.correctOption: PCI within 60 minutes / fibrinolysis within 12 hours
questions.explanation: The PACSA STEMI Reperfusion flowchart suggests percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) if available within 60 minutes. Otherwise, thrombolysis with tenecteplase (IV) should be given within 12 hours of symptom onset provided there are no contraindications.

questions.prompt: What is the most likely site of occlusion in this case?
questions.explanation: The RCA supplies the inferior wall in those with a right-dominant circulation (~80% of people). Less commonly, an inferior STEMI is caused by occlusion of the LCx in those with a left-dominant circulation (~20% of people).

questions.prompt: When would you expect this patient's troponin levels to peak?
questions.explanation: Cardiac troponins begin to rise 4 - 6 hours after symptom onset and peak at 18 - 24 hours.

questions.prompt: What is the most likely diagnosis?
What is the role of calculating a CHADSVASC score in a patient with AF?
options: To decide between rate and rhythm control strategies
To determine the risk of stroke
To determine the risk of a heart failure exacerbation
To determine the risk of DVT
questions.correctOption: To determine the risk of stroke

questions.prompt: This patient is stable with a CHADSVASC score of 3. What is your management plan?
options: Rate control, anticoagulation, cardioversion to be considered
Rhythm control, anticoagulation, cardioversion to be considered
Rate control, antiplatelets, cardioversion to be considered
questions.correctOption: Rate control, anticoagulation, cardioversion to be considered

questions.prompt: What would you use for rate control in this patient?
options: Beta blockers and non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers
Amiodarone and dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers
questions.correctOption: Beta blockers and non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers

questions.prompt: What are our first-line options for pharmacological cardioversion in this patient?
options: Beta blockers and non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers
Amiodarone and dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers

questions.prompt: Recall the MOA of flecainide and sotalol, respectively.
options: Sodium channel blockade, potassium channel blockade
Potassium channel blockade, sodium channel blockade
Calcium channel blockade, sodium channel blockade
Potassium channel blockade, calcium channel blockade
questions.correctOption: Sodium channel blockade, potassium channel blockade

investigations.name: CT Angiogram
investigations.result: Dissection flap extending from the ascending aorta to the descending aorta

investigations.name: Stress Test
investigations.result: Patient condition becomes a lot worse...

questions.prompt: What is the most likely diagnosis?
What could you expect to hear on auscultation?
options: Systolic murmur radiating to the carotids
Diastolic murmur over the aortic area
questions.correctOption: Diastolic murmur over the aortic area
questions.explanation: If the dissection involves the ascending aorta or aortic root, it may pull apart the aortic valve leaflets or disrupt their alignment, preventing them from closing properly during diastole. This results in an aortic regurgitation murmur.

questions.prompt: In an aortic dissection, between which layers of the aorta does the blood collect?
questions.explanation: An aortic dissection is a tear in the intimal layer of the aortic wall, causing blood to flow between and splitting apart the tunica intima and media.

questions.prompt: You provide fentanyl PCA for pain relief. What is the most appropriate next step?
questions.explanation: A target HR of 60-80 should be reached via an IV bolus & infusion of esmolol / labetalol / metoprolol. Following this, a target BP of 100-120 systolic (right arm likely most accurate) should be reached using sodium nitroprusside IV.

questions.prompt: Are you going to call cardiothoracic surgery?
questions.explanation: In Stanford A dissections, surgical repair represents the mainstay of treatment. Stanford B dissections can be managed medically.

cases.stem: 32F presents with worsening shortness of breath and wheezing for the past hour. She is unable to speak in full sentences. She has a past history of asthma.

investigations.name: Coags
investigations.result:
PT: 13.5: (11–14 seconds)
INR: 1.1: (0.8–1.2)
aPTT: 32: (25–35 seconds)
D-dimer: 0.3: (<0.5 µg/mL FEU)
Fibrinogen: 2.8: (2.0–4.0 g/L)

investigations.name: EUC
investigations.result:
Sodium: 140: (135–145 mmol/L)
Potassium: 4.0: (3.5–5.0 mmol/L)
Chloride: 102: (95–105 mmol/L)
Bicarbonate: 24: (22–28 mmol/L)
Urea: 5.0: (2.5–7.5 mmol/L)
Creatinine: 80: (60–110 µmol/L)

investigations.name: LFT
investigations.result:
Bilirubin: 10: (0–20 µmol/L)
ALT: 25: (10–40 U/L)
AST: 20: (10–40 U/L)
ALP: 80: (30–120 U/L)
GGT: 25: (10–50 U/L)
Total Protein: 70: (60–80 g/L)
Albumin: 45: (35–50 g/L)

investigations.name: CXR
investigations.result: Lungs clear, no evidence of pneumothorax

questions.prompt: What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Given an absence of history / features indicating pneumothorax, COPD or infection, asthma is the most likely explanation for her symptoms. A peak expiratory flow (PEF) of 33-50% of the predicted value is indicative of a severe attack. Other features indicating a severe attack include: 
 
 • Inability to complete sentences in one breath 
 • Respiratory rate of ≥ 25 
 • Tachycardia of ≥ 120 bpm

questions.prompt: What is your interpretation of her ABG?
questions.explanation:
The ABG shows a slightly basic blood pH with a low CO2 and normal HCO3, which suggests a respiratory alkalosis without metabolic compensation. Respiratory alkalosis is a common finding in the early stages of a severe asthma exacerbation due to initial hyperventilation. 
 
Respiratory acidosis can be seen in later presentations with deterioration and significant airway obstruction leading to CO2 retention.

questions.prompt: What is your initial definitive management?
questions.explanation:
For the immediate management of severe asthma, the National Asthma Council (asthmahandbook.org.au) suggests salbutamol (12 puffs) + ipratropium bromide 
(8 puffs) via a pressurised metered dose inhaler (pMDI) and spacer. 
 
If the patient cannot tolerate a spacer, 5mg nebule salbutamol + 500 mcg ipratropium bromide is to be given in a nebulised solution. 
 
Supplementary oxygen should also be given, with a target O2 saturation of 93-95%

questions.prompt: What drug class does ipratropium bromide belong to?
questions.explanation: Ipratropium bromide (Atrovent) is a short acting muscarinic antagonist (SAMA), along with oxitropium bromide.

questions.prompt: The patient has a poor response to your initial management. What should we give next?
questions.explanation:
Following a poor response to initial therapy, the National Asthma Council suggests adding 10 mmol of IV magnesium sulfate over 20 minutes. Add-on treatment options such as oral prednisolone / IV hydrocortisone may also be considered within the first hour. 
 
IV salbutamol and aminophylline are considered if these interventions are ineffective. 
 
Formoterol + budesonide is used for long-term maintenance therapy in chronic obstructive pulmonary diseases.

questions.prompt: Which of the following is a hallmark pathological airway change in asthma?
options: Destruction of alveolar walls and capillaries
Subepithelial collagen deposition and goblet cell hyperplasia
Hyaline membrane formation and alveolar edema
questions.correctOption: Subepithelial collagen deposition and goblet cell hyperplasia
questions.explanation:
The pathological features of airway remodelling in asthma include: 
 
 • Goblet cell metaplasia and hyperplasia
 • Smooth muscle hypertrophy and hyperplasia
 • Increased vascularity
 • Subepithelial collagen deposition

questions.prompt: What is the role of IgE in allergic asthma?
options: IgE is released by mast cells in response to allergen
Triggers mast cell degranulation upon allergen re-exposure
questions.correctOption: Triggers mast cell degranulation upon allergen re-exposure
questions.explanation: IgE mediates acute and chronic inflammation in allergic asthma. Allergen-specific IgE binds to mast cells, and re-exposure leads to mast cell degranulation, releasing mediators like histamine and leukotrienes that cause bronchoconstriction and airway edema. IgE also sustains chronic inflammation by recruiting eosinophils and promoting airway remodeling.
